title: Banking Basics in Canada
description: Understand how to choose your first bank and the difference between accounts.

content.title: Chequing vs. Savings
content.text: A chequing account is for daily spending (paying bills, groceries). A savings account is for keeping money long-term and earns a small amount of interest. Most Canadian banks offer 'Newcomer Packages' with no monthly fees for the first year.

content.title: Avoid ATM Fees
content.text: Using an ATM that doesn't belong to your bank can cost you $2 to $5 per withdrawal. Stick to your own bank's machines to keep your money in your pocket.

quiz.question: Which account should you use for your daily grocery shopping?
quiz.explanation: Chequing accounts are designed for frequent daily transactions, while savings accounts are for building a safety net.

quiz.question: True or False: Most major Canadian banks offer free banking for newcomers for a limited time.
quiz.explanation: True! Most of the 'Big Five' banks have newcomer programs that waive monthly fees for 6 to 12 months.

title: Building Credit in Canada
description: Learn why credit scores matter and how to build a strong history from scratch.

content.title: What is a Credit Score?
content.text: In Canada, your credit score is like a financial report card. It tells banks and landlords how trustworthy you receive money. Scores range from 300 to 900. A score above 660 is generally considered 'Good'.

content.title: How to Build It
content.text: The easiest way to start is to get a secured credit card or a beginner card, use it for small purchases (like groceries), and pay it off IN FULL every month.

quiz.question: What is considered a 'Good' credit score in Canada?
quiz.explanation: Scores range from 300-900. 660+ is considered good, giving you access to better loans and apartments.

quiz.question: True or False: Checking your own credit score hurts your rating.
quiz.explanation: False! Checking your own score is a 'soft inquiry' and has zero negative impact.

quiz.question: What is the 'Golden Rule' of credit cards?
options: Pay off your balance in full every month
Keep a high balance to show you have money
quiz.explanation: Paying in full avoids interest charges and builds a strong payment history.

title: Smart Saving: TFSA vs. RRSP
description: Learn about Canada's two most popular tax-free ways to grow your money.

content.title: The TFSA
content.text: The Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) lets you save for anything (a car, a house, or a trip). You don't pay any tax on the profit you make inside this account, and you can withdraw money anytime for free.

content.title: The RRSP
content.text: The Registered Retirement Savings Plan (RRSP) is for long-term retirement. Putting money in here can lower your annual income tax bill, but you usually pay tax later when you take the money out in retirement.

quiz.question: Which account allows you to withdraw money at any time without paying tax on the gains?
quiz.explanation: The TFSA is highly flexible, allowing tax-free withdrawals for any purpose at any time.

quiz.question: When is the best time to focus on an RRSP?
options: When you are in a high tax bracket
When you first arrive with no job
When you want to buy a TV next month
quiz.explanation: RRSPs provide a tax deduction, so they are most effective when you are earning a higher income and want to pay less tax now.

title: The 30% Rule & Rent Reporting
description: Pro-tips to boost your credit score faster.

content.title: The 30% Utilization Rule
content.text: If your credit limit is $1,000, try to never owe more than $300 (30%). Using too much of your available credit makes you look 'risky' to banks, even if you pay it all back.

content.title: Reporting Your Rent
content.text: In Canada, your rent payments aren't automatically sent to credit bureaus. You can use services like Borrowell or SingleKey to report your on-time rent to Equifax, which can help build your score without debt.

quiz.question: If your credit card limit is $2,000, what is the 'safe' balance to stay under?
quiz.explanation: $600 is 30% of $2,000. Staying under this threshold helps keep your credit score healthy.

quiz.question: Does paying your rent automatically help your Canadian credit score?
options: No, you must use a third-party reporting service
Only if you pay in cash
quiz.explanation: Rent is not automatically reported. You must sign up for a service to have your rent payments count toward your credit history.
